intro: Diphelypaea, commonly known as the water clover, is a genus of aquatic plants belonging to the family Araceae. These plants are characterized by their floating leaves that are often divided into small, finger-like segments, resembling the leaves of the common clover. Diphelypaea species are typically found in slow-moving freshwater environments such as ponds and marshes. They play an important role in aquatic ecosystems by providing habitat for small aquatic organisms. Their rapid growth and ability to form dense mats make them both ecologically significant and sometimes invasive in non-native regions.
